body:
I am having the same problem! I want to find the best model over multiple runs, but since I can have multiple checkpoints over time in one run and the metrics (which are logged with the "step" in each run) seem not to be connected to the logged models (which are just connected to a run if I understand correctly?)

any idea on how to do this?

Thanks for your answer! :)

tbh I find it a little bit weird though, that to do one of the major things that MLflow Tracking (I assume) is designed for (namely tracking machine learning runs and then using those tracked runs to get the best trained model) has to be done with a hack?

Am I misunderstanding something in the design of MLflow or what it should be used for?
How are you supposed to use MLflow to find the best checkpoint for a deep learning model that is trained over many epochs?

I understand your use case, but I'm not sure how logging artifacts with step solves your problem. For instance, logging metrics with step is obviously crucial; if I wanted to check the step with the lowest loss, I could look at the loss vs step graph and find the global minimum. I can't do this with artifacts because they can't be numerically represented.
You could log the "best" model (as defined by some metric you want) by calling log_artifact accordingly in your training loop.

Yes, exactly! And after I looked at the loss vs step graph and found the step with the lowest loss, I will now want to of course get the checkpoint I saved for that step, since that corresponds to my best model I now might want to deploy.  

It's possible I have some huge misunderstanding here somewhere, so let me try to make my thinking even more explicit:

I am training a ResNet for an image classification task on a custom dataset. Just like Andrew Ng would want I have chose my single number evaluation metric. Now, after every epoch of training I will evaluate my current model on a validation set, log the metrics and if the evaluation metric I care about is the best I have seen so far, I will want to save my model (which as I understand in MLflow would mean logging a checkpoint of the model as an artifact). Of course as I progress with training most likely there will be multiple epochs where the evaluation metric is the best I have seen so far (after the first epoch this will be my best model for sure, hopefully after the second epoch it will be even better), so I will end up with multiple checkpoints logged as I train for many epochs. 
Now at the end of the training I would like to find the checkpoint where my single evaluation metric did best and deploy that model to production. 

This seems like a pretty standard use-case to me (is it not? is logging all the best models a bad idea? how else would I do it?) and it is still not clear to me how MLflow supports this (since there seems no way to connect the checkpoints (artifacts) I logged to the value of the metric at a given step. Am I missing something? Should I not be saving my model checkpoints as artifacts? Is there another way to connect my model checkpoints with the metrics I am logging with MLflow).

Thanks already for your patience in going through this. :)

I think the misunderstanding here is that a 'step' is not a snapshot of your entire training session at a given point of time. Rather, it is simply the data used to relate metrics and parameters to time so they can be viewed graphically. Artifacts are semantically related with a _run_, not a step, so logging an artifact with step doesn't make a lot of sense to me. 
More simply, if your motivation is to log an artifact against the step that saw the lowest validation loss, you could achieve this with a combination of @dbczumar 's suggestion (which attaches the step to the artifact name) and keeping track of the lowest validation loss so far in your loop:
```python
if val_loss < lowest_val_loss:
    mlflow.log_artifact(...)
    lowest_val_loss = val_loss
```
This would log multiple artifacts where the validation loss was at a global minimum (which could have occurred multiple times). If you want just _one_, you could do something like:
```python
if val_loss < lowest_val_loss:
   best_model = your_model
   lowest_val_loss = val_loss
```
and then call `mlflow.log_artifact` on `your_model` once after your training loop.

I see, but then I think this is not really a misunderstanding then. I guess my point from the very beginning was that we seem to give up a lot of flexibility by only relating artifacts to *runs* and not to specific snapshots of training.

Don't you agree that it makes much more sense to ask the question: "How well does this model do on my validation set?" and "What is the best model I trained?" rather than to ask "How does the learning curve of the training run this model was trained with look like?" and "What was the best run I had?". By just associating a model with a run we enable people to answer the second type of question. To answer the first I need to associate a model with a specific metric and using the step when the metric and model were logged seem a natural way to do this.

I am sorry if all this sounds a lot like complaining to you, but it's really just meant as a suggestion for improvement. I know MLflow would be a much, much more valuable tool to our team if it allowed us to programmatically query and compare different models and programmatically deploy the best models from our training runs. 

On the MLflow website it already says that you can

"Query and compare runs using any data analysis tool of your choice, for example, pandas."

But at the end of the day no-one cares about what their best *run* was. You want to know what your best *model* was.

In any case, thanks for open-sourcing a tool like this and patiently listening to feedback from random strangers on the internet! ðŸš€you guys rock!

@dbczumar would you mind re-opening the issue? I feel like it is not resolved. :) 
would also be happy to open a new one if you prefer that, since I feel this is less about logging artifacts with steps, but more about how to connect metrics with models and how to get the best model from a run.

@timonbimon Absolutely! Reopening it now. If possible, can you provide a step-by-step walkthrough of your current model training and model selection workflow, as well as a walkthrough of your preferred workflow? It would be useful to see how associating a `step` with an artifact would help to simplify model selection for your use case.
@timonbimon - any update on your use case?

Stepping in for @timonbimon here:

The current workflow is more or less as follows:
 - Have a number of runs in parallel, each:
   - Logs all the usual training and validation metrics.
   - Stores a checkpoint after each epoch (we're running PBT with `ray`, so it's intrinsically necessary).
   - Checks if this particular epoch was the best seen so far, and if so stores the epoch number in a tag `best_step`. Also stores a tag `best_step_value` with the corresponding best metric value.
   - The above found best checkpoint is logged as an `artifact` with the `artifact_path` being the epoch number / training step.
 - A central engine then looks at all runs, for each gets the `best_step_value` tag, and compares. 
 - It then picks the best one, and gets the corresponding `best_step` tag from the run.
 - Constructs the corresponding artifact path from the `best_step`.
 - Finally the logged artifact for the globally best checkpoint is retrieved.

If artifacts were intrinsically connected to step, the step casting into `artifact_path` could be completely avoided.
